Message.Issue: 'POIInteractiveSessionArchive.POIInteractiveSessionArchive(string, Dictionary<string, string>)' locks on a reference of type 'string'. Replace this with a lock against an object with strong-identity.
'POIInteractiveSessionArchive.joinSessionIfOpen()' locks on a reference of type 'string'. Replace this with a lock against an object with strong-identity.

Message.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Message.Issue: The query string passed to 'MySqlCommand.MySqlCommand(string, MySqlConnection)' in 'POIProxyDbManager.deleteFromTable(string, Dictionary<string, object>)' could contain the following variables 'tableName'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

Message.TypeName: Do not dispose objects multiple times
Message.Issue: Object 'writeStream' can be disposed more than once in method 'POIProxyDataHandler.handleSnapshotMsgReceived(POIPushMsg, POIUser)'. To avoid generating a System.ObjectDisposedException you should not call Dispose more than one time on an object.: Lines: 55

Rule.TypeName: Do not dispose objects multiple times
Rule.Name: Do not dispose objects multiple times
Rule.Description: A correctly implemented Dispose method can be called multiple times without throwing an exception. However, this is not guaranteed and to avoid generating a System.ObjectDisposedException you should not call Dispose more than one time on an object.
Rule.Resolution: Object {0} can be disposed more than once in method {1}. To avoid generating a System.ObjectDisposedException you should not call Dispose more than one time on an object.: Lines: 55

Rule.Name: Do not lock on objects with weak identity
Rule.Description: Don't take locks on objects that may bleed across AppDomains or that don't have a strong identity.
Rule.Resolution: {0} locks on a reference of type {1}. Replace this with a lock against an object with strong-identity.

Rule.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Rule.Name: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Rule.Description: A SQL command string built from user input is vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. Microsoft SQL Server and other database servers support stored procedures and parameterized SQL queries, which reduce the risk of injection attacks.
Rule.Resolution: The query string passed to {0} in {1} could contain the following variables {2}. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.
